title.value: Optimisation of quantitative brain diffusion-relaxation MRI acquisition protocols with physics-informed machine learning
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly stated at the beginning of the text, indicating the primary focus of the research.
title.quote: Optimisation of quantitative brain diffusion-relaxation MRI acquisition protocols with physics-informed machine learning

extractions.description: This paper presents a physics-informed machine learning framework to optimize MRI acquisition protocols, specifically focusing on diffusion-relaxation MRI to enhance efficiency and maintain accuracy. It utilizes physics-informed and data-driven methods to select optimal subsets of measurements to predict non-measured signals and estimate quantitative parameters.

type.justification: The research involves experiments using both synthetic and in vivo data for training and validation, and comparisons with other selection procedures, suggesting an empirical approach focused on experimentation and validation.
type.quote: In vivo and synthetic brain 5D-Diffusion-T 1 -T 2 ^{∗} -weighted MRI data obtained from five healthy subjects were used for training and validation, and from a sixth participant for testing.

name.justification: The research is focused on optimizing MRI acquisition protocols, which falls under the domain of medical imaging.
name.quote: Optimisation of quantitative brain diffusion-relaxation MRI acquisition protocols with physics-informed machine learning

name.justification: The paper discusses the use of machine learning methods, specifically physics-informed and data-driven approaches for improvement in MRI protocols.
name.quote: This work proposes a physics-informed learning framework to extract an optimal subset of diffusion-relaxation MRI measurements for enabling shorter acquisition times.

name.justification: The paper focuses on extracting quantitative measures from MRI data, which is a specific application within the broader field of medical imaging.
name.quote: Quantitative MRI aims to extract reproducible measures more directly related to tissue properties.

name.justification: The paper describes using concrete autoencoders to select a subset of MRI measurements, which include the concrete autoencoder method as a referenced technique.
name.quote: Our hypothesis is that physics-informed optimisation identifies sub-sets of MRI measurements that provide, per unit time, better estimates of quantitative parameters characterising diffusion and relaxation com-pared to full data-driven or other methods. To test this hypothesis, the estimation of quantitative parameters and prediction of the MRI signal was compared between the proposed approach, the original concrete autoencoder method, manually selected protocols, and CRLB optimisation.

is_contributed.justification: The concrete autoencoder is mentioned as one of the referenced methods against which this study's methods are compared, not as a novel contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: compared between the proposed approach, the original concrete autoencoder method, manually selected protocols, and CRLB optimisation.

is_executed.justification: The paper implements and compares the concrete autoencoder method as part of the study's approach to optimization.
is_executed.quote: To test this hypothesis, the estimation of quantitative parameters and prediction of the MRI signal was compared between...the original concrete autoencoder method.

is_compared.justification: The concrete autoencoder method is compared against the proposed physics-informed and data-driven methods in terms of its effectiveness in optimizing MRI measurement subsets.
is_compared.quote: To test this hypothesis, the estimation of quantitative parameters and prediction of the MRI signal was compared between...the original concrete autoencoder method.

referenced_paper_title.value: Concrete Autoencoders for Differentiable Feature Selection and Reconstruction
referenced_paper_title.justification: This title is inferred from typical academic reporting as it aligns with the description of concrete autoencoder methods.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Concrete Autoencoders for Differentiable Feature Selection and Reconstruction

name.justification: This dataset, used for training, validation, and testing, is specifically mentioned in relation to the paper's experiments and analyses.
name.quote: In vivo and synthetic brain 5D-Diffusion-T 1 -T 2 ^{∗} -weighted MRI data obtained from five healthy subjects were used for training and validation, and from a sixth participant for testing.

referenced_paper_title.value: Acquiring and predicting multidimensional diffusion (MUDI) data: An open challenge
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is part of the MUDI challenge, which is referenced in the context of dataset usage.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The data used in this study were provided by the organisers of the MUDI challenge.

name.justification: Dipy is mentioned explicitly as a library used for co-registration of diffusion-weighted images, indicating its usage in the study.
name.quote: The data were preprocessed as previously described (Pizzolato et al., 2020). Briefly, this included...co-registration of the diffusion-weighted images using Dipy (Garyfallidis et al., 2014)

referenced_paper_title.quote: Dipy, a library for the analysis of diffusion MRI data
